comments.commentBody: With campaigns costing so much these days, I support the decision of the Supreme Court.  Let's say I decide to run for elected office to represent the God fearing people of Tennessee.  Well I don't have enough money in my savings account to run a successful campaign.  I'm going to need some rich dudes to support me.  The decision by the Supreme Court, the highest law in that law, would make that happen.  That's why this decision supports the common man.
Agree entirely. It should now be obvious to anyone that we  no longer are. Democracy or a republic. It's pointless to vote. I give up.

Lets get rid of voting altogether. Let the rich bid against each other auction-style for their respective candidates with the money raised going into the treasury. It would save us all the indignity of sitting through the circuses they call elections in which no matter who you vote for Wall Street always wins.

While many are horrified by the latest rulings, the truth is that this country has ALWAYS been run by the 1%. Episodically they feel compelled to make concessions when we go out on strike or set fires in the streets in sufficient numbers to get their attention. And of course sometimes they fight amongst themselves and that can open up opportunities to make demands on them.

The Supreme Court rulings only make the whole arrangement a little more naked. As far as I'm concerned that is a good thing. It might hasten the day that we finally overthrow this dictatorship of the rich. We don't actually have to live like this. We can throw these parasites off our backs just as soon as we decide to.

Citizens should be able to spend as much as they wish of their funds to finance the candidates of their choice.  With one restriction, they can only finance candidates they have the right to vote for, that is representatives in their district, senators in their state, and the president and vice president of their country
Conservatives in California would gladly trade some of those peels if Democrats Leland Yee, Rod Wright, and Ron Calderon hadn't already gone bananas in more "legitimate" campaign circumstances.

I think the concern that we're peeling away protections against corruption one at a time is certainly valid.

At this time, I don't see the McCutcheon decision as quite a bit factor as others do, because I think may big donors value the secrecy of their social welfare groups. This decision doesn't peel that away from direct candidate committee donations (yet). I think some of the most corrupting influences will remain in those Social Welfare groups for now. But look for donor disclosure, along with dollar limits and restrictions on corporations to be challenged next in the courts.

We need to amend the Constitution to make it clear that corporations are not "persons" and that Congress is authorized to regulate campaign financing and contributions. How do European countries handle this?

The time has come to dispense with all the awe and reverence Americans feel for the U.S. Constitution. Anyone familiar with the actual circumstances under which it was drafted understands that it was essentially a political power grab by the wealthiest interests in the country -- the merchant bankers and the plantation owners, AKA the 1% of the late 18th century. The composition of that ruling class has changed in various ways since then, but we have always been ruled by what can only be called a dictatorship of the 1% and the Constitution has consistently served as an instrument of that rule.

The Constitution needs to be thrown out and a new and genuinely democratic one needs to be written, not according to the provisions in the current constitution either, but by a real constituent assembly that genuinely represents all sectors of society. It will take a revolutionary situation to force such a change, but that is where we are and what is needed.
Maybe that's because the Republicans are owned lock, stock and barrel by the rich and multinational corporations.

A solution can be found here:
www.Movetoamend.org

This organization is the viable movement for an Amendment to the Constitution to refute the politically oriented leanings and decisions of the Supreme Court.

Also, this just in regarding Wisconsin - the state of Republican Congressman Paul Ryan.

"Wisconsinites voted by huge majorities in thirteen communities in favor of instructing Wisconsin’s Congressional delegation to propose and support — and the Wisconsin state legislature ratify — an amendment to the United States Constitution that clarifies three issues:
1) that money is not speech; 2) that corporations are not entitled to the same rights as natural persons; and 3) that Congress and the states can limit election-related spending to ensure that all citizens, regardless of wealth, can express their views to one another and their government on a level playing field.”

This continues our trend of never yet failing when the vote for the We the People Amendment is put directly in front of The People at the ballot box. Congratulations .... to our volunteer organizers in Wisconsin!

Wisconsin's victories come on the heels of an exciting March in New Hampshire where organizers used the historic town meeting process to place resolutions of support for the 28th Amendment in front of their communities for direct discussion and deliberation. Move to Amend organizers and others were successful in passing resolutions through town meetings in 48 communities across the state!"

To stop voting is not an acceptable answer.
On the contrary - voting is the main and possibly the only answer to the problem situation.
Create more informed voters through persuasion and disseminating information widely and continually.

To stop voting will lead to fascism.
Give thought and study to the following quote from Mussolini.
"Fascism should more properly be called corporatism, since it is the merger of state and corporate power."

(Why give Putin any reason to start a war with us. And why put Europe on the horns of a dilemma.)

With that pungent thought I shall leave you.
Great points. I've always thought the decision of the Roberts Court to ban public matching funds was its most illogical, lawless and partisan.

The solution is at the level of the legislation: make elections funded by public money where each person contributes a dollar or two. Would that work?  Shouldn't a few hundred dollars per year be enough to run the entire system of elections?
That is exactly the intended result.

The tragedy of this is not so much that rich people can buy so much, it is more that little guy's, like me, will say what's the point? Why should I bother to donate my paltry $50 or $100 for some Congressional or state election when some fat cat can buy the candidate with a stroke of a pen. Democracy is going to hell in a hand basket and the Supreme Court is leading the journey.
They already are, but folks are struggling to get to the auction due to traffic on the bridge.
Soon elections will be auctioned at Christie's.

"Will violence be the only option?"  You conveniently forget that if the public felt what you claim it feels, there is the option of amending the Constitution accordingly.  Funny how those who claim overwhelming support for their views on gun control, campaign spending limits, etc., seem to always forget this option.

Thomas Jefferson's support for revolution every 20 years has been coming to mind lately. A case can be made for that pattern thru US history--most recently represented by FDR, JFK, Reagan, and GWB. While the JFK era was one of can-do reaching for the moon, Reagan's era retracted government's power and reach. That GWB took office without the popular vote underscores the political sea change he ushered in: When the American political culture went beyond valuing small government all the way to abandoning self-government and allowing corporations (finance, energy, military) to rule.

My worry: Every earlier sea change was reversible peacefully through the ballot box when the American people were ready to move on. However, the 2000 revolution has had qualitatively different results: As corporations take more control, the ability of the people peacefully to move back to self-government is being impaired. We're already seeing super-majorities of the population support things like strengthening social security; adopting responsible gun safety laws; taking action on climate change; improving public schools; and getting money out of politics, while our governments move instead on policies sought only by corporations. Assuming the American people will be ready in 2020 to restore self-government, will we be able to do that peacefully as in past revolutions? Or will violence be the only option?

Frank: I'd be interested to know what your previous policy covered- and what it didn't cover (e.g., hospitalization?).  If you couldn't afford an "Obamacare" policy, did you check to see whether you qualified for a subsidy?

It really depends on the child. My parents leveraged the idea of 'allowance' to try to teach us good savings habits and the benefit of compounding interest (if we didn't draw our allowance weekly, allowing them to hold it, we charged them interest for the privilege. Three children, three different outcomes:

1 - I learned the benefit of spending other peoples money. Figuring that I could get someone else to buy me what I wanted (mostly grandparents), I didn't draw my allowance for several years, and when I did, it went straight into a savings account. Figures on a page were real to me, particularly as they increased.

2 - my middle brother had to see - and spend - his allowance money with regularity in order to understand the tangible benefit it held for him: the goods it purchased.

3 - my youngest brother drew his allowance weekly and then almost always lost it.

And yet we grew into three well-adjusted adults who all saved, invested and spent their money fairly wisely. The moral of the story? You keep learning well past your 'Bank of Dad' years.

Dave seems to phone it in a bit these days, but to some degree he is a conscience to the nation, and it a comfortable experience.  He should continue as long as he wants - and he says he is ready.  The question is how much he shall miss it.  And it seems he wants to go out in top form, and extremely relevant.  Thanks for a good run Dave.

Do you really think Obama had a mandate to enact Medicare for all? That's not the platform he ran on. Rather, both Obama and Hillary Clinton proposed plans very similar to the ACA during their campaigns. Regardless, Obama couldn't do anything without the approval of Congress, and a majority of Democrats didn't even support Medicare for all. So voters certainly had no reason to expect there would be Medicare for all, beyond wishful thinking.

'Obama and the Democrats had a window to enact a better health care reform that would have been better for the nation and better politically in the long run because we'd all be living the benefits of it.'

Um, no, they didn't -- at least not on the terms you dictate. Between Senator Franken being seated late in the session and Senator Kennedy's death, the window was quite narrow. There were two Senators in the Democratic caucus who made it publicly quite clear they would not support even a public option, let alone anything approaching single payer.

Do the math -- at the time, it took 60 Senators and 218 House Members to pass a law. Those numbers did not exist for single payer in 2010. Or within my lifetime. (I was born during the Kennedy administration.)

The House, with only Democratic votes, barely passed the ACA, and only after rolling back a few things.

The ACA is flawed, but was politically achievable. It accomplished something Presidents had been trying to do for 97 years.

It was forward movement -- progress. Letting the good, or even the better, be the enemy of the perceived perfect is bad governance. We've had way too much of that from the side who wanted no reform and no victories at all the President.

Forward.

Not all those 7 million you mention were uninsured. I suspect a large part already had insurance and at least a few of them received worse coverage at higher prices and my have had to change doctors. Out of about 20 middle class people I have spoken to directly all except for one couple have had their premiums go up drastically (40% or more), co-pays and deductibles much higher, complicated changes in drug, tests, out placement, hospital, ambulance and other coverage changed for the WORSE.

Everyone here can continue to deny that there are many real people that have been harmed by ACA and refute my comments but it is reality. We will see the results in November. I am willing to bet Democrats will lose elections because of it.

Simple Obama said we could keep our policies & doctors and that we would see savings of $2500 per family per year and that was how insurance would be provided to the people he wanted to help. Those are the lies and fraud I speak of.

There are 314 million Americans. Just over 7 million otherwise uninsured Americans now have health care that they presumably will be happy with, thanks to Obamacare. But, that means there are 307 million Americans available to be frightened into thinking that Democrats have changed health care in a way that puts their health and financial security at risk. Change is scary. People don't think rationally.

The advantage in Medicare for all would have been that all Americans would have experienced it. The 170 million Americans currently receiving health care through employers would wake up to the news that no longer did their health security depend upon their job security. It would be pretty difficult to frighten them.

Obama and the Democrats had a window to enact a better health care reform that would have been better for the nation and better politically in the long run because we'd all be living the benefits of it. He had a mandate to do it, and he squandered it away. Now Democrats are left to defend an incremental reform that actually impacts very few people, in the face of apocalyptic, fear-mongering demagoguery.

I'm not looking forward to November.
If the enrollment period were continuous it wouldn't be feasible to subject the uninsured to a monetary penalty.

Craig Ferguson is your man. There is a whole untapped side to Ferguson which would lend itself to serious interviews, with serious people (together with his own injection of humor of course) that nobody else can offer.

My vote is cast.

I just want to say that over the years, I've enjoyed how we've looked back at the Carson influence on our culture.  Now it's time for some serious Letterman appreciation.  He affected humor and just general ways-of-being in this country in ways that I don't think enough people acknowledge or appreciate.  Now I just have hurry up and become a famous actor, musician, or winning ballplayer so I can get on the show before it's too late!
Probably the least interesting or funny person on TV.

When Letterman was on Carson, I never laughed so hard. It is possible, though, to say that Letterman's questioning of John McCain's honesty when he canceled due to "the economy cratering" and the Republican presidential candidate's defense of his vice presidential choice were the key things to crater McCain. There, too, Letterman made it exquisitely personal, in a way that reverberated with so many people, including me.
Regardless, they are both simply talk show hosts. Nothing more, nothing less. Now turn off the tube and read a book or something.
I think you were watching a different show.

Actually, Dave has been one of the most flagrantly unfair talk show personalities around. He uses the guise of humor to promote liberal politicians and to denigrate conservative politicians. Looking back on his 'jokes' one will find many examples of mean and cruel humor directed at conservatives, and light hearted jocularity for liberals. It's all one way, all the time. No balance and therefore no humor. Humor is like Jon Stewart who rips both sides all the time. Dave is an example of cruel humor.. just my opinion (and most people I know)
